subject: Photography
title: Macro: The Tiny World
description: A 60-second lesson on Macro: The Tiny World.

hook.text: An ant carrying a leaf. A dewdrop on a petal. Macro photography reveals worlds invisible to the naked eye.

buildup.text: Macro photography magnifies tiny subjects to life-size or larger, showing details the eye can't resolve.

discovery.text: At macro scales, a fly's eye becomes a geodesic dome. A leaf surface becomes a green mountain range.

twist.text: Depth of field at macro distances is razor thin â€” often just millimeters. Focus stacking combines dozens of shots.

climax.text: Macro photography proves that wonder doesn't require exotic locations. It's in your backyard, under a leaf.

punchline.text: The smaller you look, the bigger the world gets.

quiz.question: Why is focus stacking used in macro photography?
options: Depth of field is so thin that multiple shots are combined for sharpness
It only works with digital cameras
